1996.Description: Initiative: A mass immunization campaign targeting children aged 5-12 years to increase measles vaccination coverage. Outcome: Significant increase in vaccination rates and reduction in measles incidence.

1997.Description: Policy Change: National Immunization Program updated to include a second dose of the measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine at age 4. Purpose: To ensure higher immunity and prevent outbreaks.

1998.Description: Initiative: Introduction of school-based vaccination programs to reach older children who missed earlier MMR doses. Impact: Increased vaccination coverage among school-aged children.

2000.Description: Objective: Set goal to eliminate measles by 2005, aligning with WHO regional goals. Strategies: High vaccination coverage, enhanced surveillance, rapid outbreak response.

2001.Description: Initiative: Strengthening of the surveillance system for better tracking of measles cases and outbreaks. Features: Laboratory confirmation for suspected cases, mandatory reporting, improved data collection.

2002.Description: Policy Framework: Planning for a strategy emphasizing high vaccination coverage, timely vaccine administration, and public awareness. Goals: Sustain measles elimination efforts and prevent reintroduction.

2003.Description: Implementation: Official launch and execution of the strategy planned in 2002. Focus: Continued high coverage, addressing vaccine hesitancy, and robust surveillance.

2005.Description: Achievement: Australia was declared measles-free, having interrupted endemic measles transmission for over three years.

2009.Description: Change: Introduction of the combined measles-mumps-rubella-varicella (MMRV) vaccine for the second dose at 18 months. Objective: Simplify vaccination schedule and increase coverage.

2013.Description: Enhancement: Improved outbreak response protocols and better integration of data systems. Impact: Quicker identification and containment of measles outbreaks.

2016.Description: Policy: Parents must ensure their children meet vaccination requirements to receive certain government benefits. Effect: Increased vaccination rates and compliance with immunization schedules.

2018.Event: Strengthened Immunization Requirements for School Entry
2018.Description: Legislation: States and territories implemented laws requiring proof of immunization for school enrollment. Goal: Ensure high vaccination coverage among school-aged children.

2020.Description: Adjustment: Efforts to maintain routine immunization schedules despite pandemic-related disruptions. Measures: Public health campaigns emphasizing the importance of continuing vaccinations.

2022.Description: Focus: Maintaining high vaccination coverage, addressing vaccine misinformation, and ensuring robust surveillance systems. Initiatives: Ongoing public health campaigns and school-based vaccination programs to prevent measles resurgence.
